case_name: Godavari Sugar Mills Ltd. v. the respondent

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 425 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 425 of 1958. Appeal by special leave from the Decision dated October 9, 1956 of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, Bombay, in Appeal  Bom.  No. 111 of 1956.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the Decision dated October 9, 1956 of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, Bombay, in Appeal Bom. No. 111 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the Decision dated October 9, 1956 of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, Bombay, in Appeal  Bom.  No. 111 of 1956. C. Setalvad, Attorney-General of India, S. N. Andley, B. Dadachanji, Rameshwar Nath and P. L. Vohra, for the appellants.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on March 15, 1960 by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. March 15. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.--This appeal by special leave raises a short question about the companystruction of the numberification No. 1131-46 issued by the Government of Bombay on October, 4, 1952, under s. 2 4  of the Bombay Industrial Relations Act, 1946  Bom. 11 of 1947   hereinafter called the Act .

facts.text: Respondent was a stenographer employed by the appellant, the Godavari Sugar Mills Ltd., at its head office in Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, who was a stenographer employed by the appellant, the Godavari Sugar Mills Ltd., at its head office in Bombay was dismissed by the appellant on April 22, 1955. He had been working as a stenographer for some years past on a salary of Rs. 135 plus Rs. 27 as dearness allowance.

facts.text: Respondent dismissed by appellant on April 22, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: at its head office in Bombay was dismissed by the appellant on April 22, 1955. He had been working as a stenographer for some years past on a salary of Rs. 135 plus Rs. 27 as dearness allowance. He was charged with having companymitted acts of disobedience and insubordination,

facts.text: Respondent worked as stenographer for some years on salary of Rs. 135 plus Rs. 27 dearness allowance.

anchor.surface_text: He had been working as a stenographer for some years past on a salary of Rs. 135 plus Rs. 27 as dearness allowance. He was charged with having companymitted acts of disobedience and insubordination, and after a proper enquiry where he was given an opportunity to defend himself,

facts.text: Respondent charged with acts of disobedience and insubordination.

anchor.surface_text: He was charged with having companymitted acts of disobedience and insubordination, and after a proper enquiry where he was given an opportunity to defend himself, he was found guilty of the alleged misconduct that is why his services were terminated that is the appellants case.

facts.text: Proper enquiry held where respondent given opportunity to defend, found guilty of misconduct, services terminated.

anchor.surface_text: and after a proper enquiry where he was given an opportunity to defend himself, he was found guilty of the alleged misconduct that is why his services were terminated that is the appellants case. The respondent challenged the legality and propriety of his dismissal by an application before the Labour Court at Bombay

facts.text: Respondent made application to Labour Court at Bombay under s.42(4) read with s.78(1)(a)(i) and (iii) of the Act challenging dismissal.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent challenged the legality and propriety of his dismissal by an application before the Labour Court at Bombay he purported to make this application under s. 42 4  read with s. 78  1   a   i  and  iii  of the Act. The appellant in reply challenged the companypetence of the application

facts.text: Appellant challenged competence of application on ground that Act did not apply to respondent's case, Labour Court no jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant in reply challenged the companypetence of the application on the ground that the Act did number apply to the respondents case, and so the Labour Court had numberjurisdiction to entertain it. Both the parties agreed that the question of jurisdiction thus raised by the appellant

facts.text: Both parties agreed that question of jurisdiction be tried as preliminary issue.

anchor.surface_text: Both the parties agreed that the question of jurisdiction thus raised by the appellant should be tried as a preliminary issue and so the Labour Court companysidered the said objection and upheld it.

facts.text: Labour Court considered objection, upheld it, held notification did not apply to head office, dismissed application.

anchor.surface_text: should be tried as a preliminary issue and so the Labour Court companysidered the said objection and upheld it. It held that the numberification in question on which the respondent relied did number apply to the head office of the appellant at Bombay accordingly the Labour Court dismissed

facts.text: Respondent appealed to Industrial Court, appeal failed, Industrial Court agreed with Labour Court.

anchor.surface_text: the respondents application. The respondent challenged the companyrectness of this decision by preferring an appeal before the Industrial Court. His appeal, however, failed since the Industrial Court agreed with the Labour. Court in holding that the numberification did number apply

facts.text: Respondent appealed to Labour Appellate Tribunal, succeeded, held notification applied to head office, set aside orders, remanded to Labour Court.

anchor.surface_text: to the head office of the appellant. The matter was then taken by the respondent before the Labour Appellate Tribunal and this time the respondent succeeded, the Labour Appellate Tribunal having held that the numberification applied to the head office and that the respondent was entitled

facts.text: Notification No. 1131-46 issued by Government of Bombay on October 4, 1952 under s. 24 of Bombay Industrial Relations Act, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: about the companystruction of the numberification No. 1131-46 issued by the Government of Bombay on October, 4, 1952, under s. 2 4  of the Bombay Industrial Relations Act, 1946  Bom. 11 of 1947   hereinafter called the Act . The respondent, who was a stenographer employed

facts.text: Notification applies to the manufacture of sugar and its by-products including (1) growing of sugarcane on farms belonging to or attached to concerns engaged in the said manufacture, and (2) all agricultural and industrial operations connected with the growing of sugarcane or the said manufacture, engaged in such concerns.

anchor.surface_text: numberification. It has been issued by the Government of Bombay in exercise of the powers companyferred on it by s. 2, sub-s.  4 , of the Act, and in supersession of an earlier numberification, and it provides that the Government of Bombay is pleased to direct that all the provisions of the said Act shall apply to the following industry, viz., the manufacture of sugar and its by-products Including  1  the growing of sugarcane on farms belonging to or attached to companycerns engaged in the said manufacture, and  2  all agricultural and industrial operations companynected with the growing of sugarcane or the said manufacture, engaged in such companycerns.

facts.text: Note in notification: For the purposes of this numberification all service or employment connected with the conduct of the above industry shall be deemed to be part of the industry when engaged in or by an employer engaged in that industry.

anchor.surface_text: Note For the purposes of this numberification all service or employment companynected with the companyduct of the above industry shall be deemed to be part of the industry when engaged in or by an employer engaged in that industry . It is significant that the numberification applies number to sugar

facts.text: Factories and offices attached to them situated at Lakshmiwadi and Sakharwadi, separated by hundreds of miles from head office at Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: In fact the factories and the offices attached to them are situated at Lakshmiwadi and Sakharwadi respectively and are separated by hundreds of miles from the head office at Bombay. The fact that the machinery required at the factories is received at the head office and has to be forwarded

facts.text: Registrar appointed under s.11 of Act consistently refused to recognise staff of head office as coming under the notification.

anchor.surface_text: Incidentally we would like to add that the registrar appointed under s. 11 of the Act has companysistently refused to recognise the staff of the head office as companying under the numberification, and it is companymon ground that the companysistent practice in the matter so far

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that notification does not apply to head office of appellant at Bombay, appeal allowed, LAT order set aside, respondent's application dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: We must accordingly hold that the Labour-Appellate Tribunal erred in law in holding that the case of the respondent was governed by the numberification. ... In the result the appeal is allowed, the order passed by the Labour Appellate Tribunal is set aside and the respondents application is dismissed.

holdings.text: The notification applies not to the sugar industry as such but to the manufacture of sugar and its by-products and has deliberately adopted a different phraseology limiting its scope despite the wide definition of 'industry' in s. 2(19).

anchor.surface_text: It is significant that the notification applies not to sugar industry as such but to the manufacture of sugar and its by-products. If the expression sugar industry had been used it would have been possible to construe that expression in a broader sense having regard to the wide definition of the word industry prescribed in s. 2(19) of the Act but the notification has deliberately adopted a different phraseology and has brought within its purview not the sugar industry as such but the manufacture of sugar and its by-products.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court notes deliberate phraseology choice to avoid broader 'sugar industry' term which would incorporate s.2(19) definition.

holdings.text: The specific inclusion of clauses (1) and (2) in the notification indicates that the first part referring to 'manufacture of sugar and its by-products' does not cover agriculture and agricultural operations, requiring harmonious construction to avoid surplusage.

anchor.surface_text: Unfortunately the Labour Appellate Tribunal has read the notification as though it referred to the sugar industry as such. That is a serious infirmity in the decision of the Labour Appellate Tribunal. Besides, the inclusion of the two items specified in cls. (1) and (2) is also significant. Section 2(19)(b)(i) shows that industry includes agriculture and agricultural operations. Now, if the manufacture of sugar and its by-products had the same meaning as the expression sugar

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clauses (1) and (2) would be superfluous under broad reading incorporating s.2(19); specific inclusion limits first part's scope.

holdings.text: The deeming note includes services or employment connected with the conduct of the industry only if engaged in that industry; head office staff at Bombay hundreds of miles away do not qualify.

anchor.surface_text: industry, then the two items added by cls. (1) and (2) would have been included in the said expression by virtue of the definition of industry itself and the addition of the two clauses would have been superfluous. The fact that the two items have been included specifically clearly indicates that the first part of the notification would not have applied to them, and it is with a view to extend the scope of the said clause that the inclusive words introducing the two items have been used. This fact also shows the limited interpretation which must be put on the words the manufacture of sugar and its by-products It is true that the note added to the notification purports to include within the scope of the notification some cases of service and employment by the, deeming process. Unfortunately the last clause in the note is unhappily worded and it is difficult to understand what exactly it was intended to mean. Even so, though by the first part of the note some kinds of service or employment are deemed to be part of the industry in question by virtue of the fact that they are connected

holdings.reasoning_summary: Strict construction of deeming clause requires services to be 'engaged in that industry'; connection alone insufficient for distant head office.

holdings.text: The notification does not apply to the head office of the appellant at Bombay or the respondent's employment there.

anchor.surface_text: We must accordingly hold that the Labour-Appellate Tribunal erred in law in holding that the case of the respondent was governed by the notification.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Based on narrow textual reading, harmonious construction, and limited deeming provision, head office excluded.

holdings.text: The respondent's application to the Labour Court was incompetent for lack of jurisdiction as the Act does not apply via the notification.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeal is allowed, the order passed by the Labour Appellate Tribunal is set aside and the respondents application is dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Notification non-applicability means Act provisions like ss.42(4), 78(1)(A)(i),(iii) not triggered, depriving Labour Court of jurisdiction.

holdings.text: In construing the notification, the prevailing practice can have no relevance.

anchor.surface_text: It is perfectly true that in construing the notification the prevailing practice can have no relevance but if after construing the notification we come to the conclusion that the head office is outside the purview of the notification it would not be irrelevant to refer to the prevailing practice which happens to be consistent with the construction we have placed on the notification.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Incidental observation; practice consistent but irrelevant to statutory construction.

holdings.text: No useful purpose will be served by considering the similar notification for textile industry under s.2(3) and related decisions.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think any useful purpose will be served by considering the said notification and the decisions thereunder.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dismisses analogy to other notifications as unhelpful.

justification_sets.label: Section 42(4) Bombay Industrial Relations Act, 1946 support

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed, order of Labour Appellate Tribunal set aside, respondent's application to Labour Court dismissed

anchor.surface_text: It is significant that the notification applies not to sugar industry as such but to the manufacture of sugar and its by-products. If the expression sugar industry had been used it would have been possible to construe that expression in a broader sense having regard to the wide definition of the word industry prescribed in s. 2(19) of the Act but the notification has deliberately adopted a different phraseology and has brought within its purview not the sugar industry as such but the manufacture of sugar and its by-products.
In the result the appeal is allowed, the order passed by the Labour Appellate Tribunal is set aside and the respondents application is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: Unfortunately the Labour Appellate Tribunal has read the notification as though it referred to the sugar industry as such. That is a serious infirmity in the decision of the Labour Appellate Tribunal. Besides, the inclusion of the two items specified in cls. (1) and (2) is also significant. Section 2(19)(b)(i) shows that industry includes agriculture and agricultural operations. Now, if the manufacture of sugar and its by-products had the same meaning as the expression sugar
In the result the appeal is allowed, the order passed by the Labour Appellate Tribunal is set aside and the respondents application is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: industry, then the two items added by cls. (1) and (2) would have been included in the said expression by virtue of the definition of industry itself and the addition of the two clauses would have been superfluous. The fact that the two items have been included specifically clearly indicates that the first part of the notification would not have applied to them, and it is with a view to extend the scope of the said clause that the inclusive words introducing the two items have been used. This fact also shows the limited interpretation which must be put on the words the manufacture of sugar and its by-products It is true that the note added to the notification purports to include within the scope of the notification some cases of service and employment by the, deeming process. Unfortunately the last clause in the note is unhappily worded and it is difficult to understand what exactly it was intended to mean. Even so, though by the first part of the note some kinds of service or employment are deemed to be part of the industry in question by virtue of the fact that they are connected
In the result the appeal is allowed, the order passed by the Labour Appellate Tribunal is set aside and the respondents application is dismissed.
